On october 25, 2011
aaperture
Go with sturdy. You get more life, which is always good, and you wont get slowed down with your heavy weapons.

Speed is what helps you get into shooting position before your enemy, or what helps you escape being surrounded. The sluggish heavy troops are the ones that are easy to kill.

On november 7, 2011
Tunkson
Fair enough. Charge is awesome, my chief of my main army uses it. It's pretty much a one-hit-kill move, at least when he uses it. Rams you and seemingly does anything between 11 and 20 damage, and in my guy's case, it always ends up in the target dying, regardless of their current or total HP. Only downside is that it backfires when in extermination missions. If you don't have frenetic then (which my guy doesn't), it doesn't take long for the rats to go nuts on your trooper in retaliation.


Now, one thing that might be a reasonable topic of discussion though, since I came across this choice for a recruit a few minutes ago:

We're talking main army here now, not recruits.

Between pilot and scout, which would you go with? We know how useless pilots are thanks to recently-made threads specifically warning against choosing pilots in main armies. However, scouts are far from useful themselves. While they raise deployment number, which is good for raid teams, in the main army, it's not that useful because you're going to end up having just 2 or 3 sets of deployments anyway. The only thing I could see going for scouts in main armies are the binoculars (job specific skill for scouts), but then, making an extra enemy troops appear - albeit with -400 initiative points - can be debating in the field of usefulness itself.

So between the two, which would you choose? (Keep in mind that you can get a vehicle even if you're not a pilot. I've seen more non-pilots with vehicles at level 7 than pilots.)

On november 7, 2011
Tunkson
Your math is fine enough to be understood, at the very least. I'm referring to the pilot's bonus of having at 25% higher chance of getting a vehicle sooner. If the pilot's bonus made up for such a drastic difference, there would be a proportionally larger amount of pilots in vehicles.
Comparing pilots with other classes, they do not appear in vehicles more often, although their profession bonus suggests this possibility. You would think that, as an example, with 4 trooper of each class, one of those 4 would have a vehicle, while 2 of 4 pilots would, but that doesn't seem to be the case. Personally, I have seen vehicles being used by more comms officers than pilots. So the bonus given to pilots isn't as grand as one would think.

On november 27, 2011
Tunkson
I myself would actually go with the commanche auto.

For starters, we're talking about a soldier here, they'll have enough HP to take in a healthy amount of damage. Then, look at your stuff, you have a BPV and a FMB, that's +2 armor and half the chance of taking a fatal hit to either head or torso. This means that your chances of ever being killed in one hit has taken a serious nosedive (which is good for your trooper).

With the commanche auto, you'll basically be a walking tank. That would probably easily make your trooper "the biggest threat", and you can be up front in everyone's face, and use the trooper as a decoy for your other troops (soldiers are the best decoys since they have more HP than anyone else), like bazookas throwers who need some time to get ready.

Pause
Having the smart skill means that us you level up you will get another weapon (some weapon), being in the main army means you will be leveling up (some time).
So... if you could pick any weapon would you even want the commanche auto? It's only average.
All Machine Guns

Damage: more then Minigun less then Gatling Gun.
Range: average, Crit: average, Bursts & Aim, average & average...
The great thing about it is the recovery time but thats all. Recovery time is good assuming that you get to fire the first shot and that you still have ammo in the gun for the next burst.
This would be a guy with Motorcycle or a spy using the Battle-Ready skill or Loader.

All of the assault Weapons and machine guns (apart from Heavy machine gun of course) suffer from ammo problems. If you pick the commanche auto there will be games were you will be stating the fight with only 1 ammo. It becomes a two skill investment for one gun.
I think it is better to first get Battle-Ready or Loader which will fix the problem before geting any of the more common skills that create the problem.

The commanche auto is as good as any weapon but then again you can get just any old weapon later on ...or maybe something even better.
On november 27, 2011
MagicDragon
With Smart, your trooper will have three skill upgrade options with each level up. Since this guy is in your main army, I would go with Friendly Fire or Adrenaline. He'll be a siting duck for now after he runs out of ammo, but there is always the possibility of him picking up a discarded weapon in a fight.

I think in the long run, Friendly Fire is a more valuable skill than the Comanche Auto or Adrenaline. Him taking Friendly Fire means no more damaging his teammates.

On february 1, 2012

On february 1, 2012
pickupsticks
His choices are: Bazooka M25 and CK-Magellan.


Depends on the rest of your troopers. If you take the M25 then that gives you more flexibility because you can choose to have him as a rocketeer or a sniper. If you have a lot of snipers already but no rocketry then the M25 might be the better choice.
Personally I'd probably go for the CK-M regardless. It's got such a high rate of fire that it's a wonderful weapon - constantly disrupting the enemy by interrupting shots and inflicting wounds that reduce the enemy performance. Getting a critical hit is a bonus. Your troopers equipment increasing accuracy makes this an even better choice.

- Cold blooded
- Barrel extension

Cold blooded is a good skill to keep the tempo of the fight in your favour, but I'd not write barrel extension off. Unless you are planning to use your trooper as a sniper only then a little extra range will often make the difference. If you're in range first then you shoot first, which can be vital. Tough call.

On february 1, 2012
pickupsticks
In my opinion Comms Officer is probably going to help your army out more, the chance to get solo missions is pretty awesome.

The other two options are both good though. He's already very hard to hit, so making him a Soldier would give him some extra survivability and make him a real nuisance. (I like unforgiving as a combo with assault rifle by the way, very nice)
Doctors seem to be offered less often, so you may want to grab that, although this might just be my luck and not actually true. Doctors are frustrating when they move away from a certain kill to go and heal someone instead, but they are invaluable. The more of your troopers have poison or twinoid the more useful your doctor becomes to deal with any friendly fire accidents.

If you can hang on a few days to get the cash to see what your other choices for the other troopers are then that may be the best course of action, to come up with a good mix for the squad. But like I said I think I'd go for Comms, not knowing what the other choices were going to be.

On february 6, 2012
mogman
Initiative is kind of an action pool of sorts. So for example... to line up a shot takes 50 initiative, shoot the shot 10 initiative, reload 100 initiative.

Speed refills that initiative, not sure if its per action or just after x number of seconds or what.

Move speed seems to just affect how far the troops will move on the amount of initiative it takes to move. So say it takes 20 initiative... Base move speed will get them 1/3 across the area. Any bonuses will still use the 20 initiative but get them more than 1/3 across the field.

Note: None of the numbers I'm using are real, just makes the explanation easier to understand.
Note 2: I'm saying most of this just on my own observations. Whether this is accurate or not I will leave to less lazy people to figure out or correct me on or whatever.

SilentPinoy
Too Long: Don't Read
-After writing down my position analysis for Ranger I kinda figured out my best option. Guess it does help a bunch to write down your ideas. So I'll just leave my half hour brainstorm up here for you to enjoy.

---------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------- ------------------

Today I come forward with another "What should my team order be?" request.

Because today "Ranger" has reached level 10 and received "Survivor".

This essentially means that I can not have Ranger in my back waves, but it also means that I may have to send back one of my other units in my composition much further than just one spot. I am posting my current order and then my own thoughts on a new order. I also need to post notes about light tank deployment because having a pair in my army does matter as they come up often that mixes my order.

Order before applying Ranger's Survivor, no tank deployment.

1. Paladin (Spy) [Primary spy deployment]
-I moved Paladin to top priority for a few reasons. Compared to Rogue, Paladin has more burst per single shot. It also helps if he's solo deployed first round because he has Camouflage which sometimes dissuades "Prioirty: Spy" and "Closest" troopers.
2. Rogue (Spy) [Secondary spy deployment]
-Rogue may have more reliability when it comes to killing units, few options for living. What's neat that I noticed is that if spies are deployed in secondary waves, they receive a little more initiative, which is perfect for Rogue if he solo deploys in secondary waves to get kills. More often have I had the situation where my second spy deploys in the later waves so it works out if Rogue is set here instead.
3. Wizard (Spy) [Bait]
-It seems many opponents have there armies swept against armies with swift and strong spies single-handedly. So it's become common practice for troops to be set to "Priority: Spy". Now the interesting thing is that sometimes they aren't too specific on which spy is more dangerous. Which is now why I have a new found respect for Wizard in my army. As long as Wizard is deployed, Paladin(which is also boosted by Camouflage) and Rogue have a chance to be ignored. It also helps that he has a fairly quick and reliable mid-range weapon now to scoop a possible kill.
4. Fighter (Comms. Officer) [Anti-Vehicle options and high level anti-personnel options]
-This is where I find survivor Fighter most effective. With On Point and Infernal Tube a quick one-two and then dying just to get up after the carnage has worked perfectly for me. I'm trying to base my Ranger positioning based on the things I notice with Fighter who has had Survivor for awhile.
5. Bard (Munitions) [Bait (Skill) and Long range support]
-I need Bard in my first wave in order for my spies to have clearance. Enemy units without Smart are victim to Bard and aim for him, in turn with Covering Fire makes quick work dispatching them.
6. Cleric (Doctor) [Combat medic with Savior skill]
-This is the spot I may put Ranger in, since with 2 Survivors putting him any sooner with only give a very low amount a good Savior target (Bard). Rogue and Paladin can't be reached quickly, Wizard is okay sometimes, Fighter has Survivor. I lose reusing Bard if I put him further back... but... (Look at Ranger's notes for my idea)
7. Barbarian (Munitions) [Secondary wave ammo distribution and Long range options placeholder)
-I can't really say much about Barbarian. I can put him anywhere on my team. If anyone has any ideas for deployment order Barbarian is not a requirement.
8. Ranger (Comms. Officer) [Gained Survivor and has Talky-Walky]
-So I've been leveling all my troops to level 10 before I save up for a 10th unit and today was Rangers turn. He had a choice between Restless and Survivor. I went with Survivor after watching the great work it has done for Fighter. So here I am trying to find a new position for him. I can see him being pushed forward into position 6 after Bard and before Cleric, giving Ranger the chance to call in Cleric. Or... I was looking at putting him in slot 5 for anti-spy options. On an enemy spy deployment I'd most likely have Wizard, Fighter, and one more deployed. With Bard he would die very quickly to the spy, but Ranger with decent speed and mid to close range weapons could deal with that. And on a no enemy spy deployment would provide options to bring in Cleric still with Talky-Walky. Another key issue is Light Tank deployment. Whenever Wizard or Bard deploys their tank I have 2 people usually join him, Fighter and whoever didn't deploy their tank. And... as I read this I kinda just realized.
9. Monk (Comms. Officer) [Awesome dude]
-He's Monk and he's awesome.
10. Savior'd
-Whoever Survivor is applied to is redeployed here.

Pilot will make you almost always get your butt to the other side, but can be sabotaged.

As Munitions, you will reload you and everyone else. I guess this is a handful skill, but since he is an Assault Trooper, dying will happen pretty fast, making this "collective bonus" to be less durable.

On february 22, 2012
Cripto
You know, when I first started my army and had little knowledge, I was given similar options which were sturdy and shock grenade. I asked people here which would be better, and I was advised to pick sturdy......In hindsight, I believe I was mislead. Shock grenade would have unquestionably been a better choice. +3 life points and increased speed with heavy weapons from sturdy is not really a game changer, neither is +5 life points from commando.

On the other hand, glue grenade makes the enemy temporarily useless and gives you the opportunity to turn a losing situation completely around. I wouldn't pass it up. Initiative is much more impacting to a game than your vitality.

On february 23, 2012
Cripto
@Cripto: Shock grenade has its value, maybe surpassing Sturdy. But since grenades are usually thrown in the beginning, Shock will be useful, while Glue won't. Everyone on the opposite side will be slowed down, but you won't be able to reach them and make this delay worthy. Unless you've got a sniper team.
Lol there's actually no question in my mind that shock surpasses sturdy, considering that I barely even notice the +3 increase in life points. Forgoing shock grenade was really a mistake; but on the bright side, I still have two equipment slots for that particular trooper which can be filled with something else later on.

About glue grenade, I think it is in fact one of the better grenades in the game, or at least one of my most feared ones. Temporarily decreasing the enemies initiative by 400 gives you a huge advantage at whatever point during the fight it is thrown. In fact, the start of a wave is normally the most important. As your army gets stronger and you begin to fight stronger armies, you'd realize that even a difference of 50 initiative can decide whether you win or lose a fight. Against a high level spy, - 400 initiative would be the death of you. Stronger armies have troopers with skills able to capitalize on even the smallest difference in initiative. It's the same with speed. It seems unimportant at first, but coupled with some skills gained in higher levels, it's worth is multiplied ten folds. Initiative is one of the most definitive aspects of a fight.

It would be a mistake to underestimate glue grenade just like I did with shock, because later on you'd realize just how helpful it could have been. I also never thought glue grenade was worth a dime, but after it being responsible for many of my losses, I've come to see the light

My question:
All other things being equal, for a trooper with an assault rifle would you take Compensator or Loader? Why?
On april 5, 2012
SilentPinoy

Loader for assault rifle. I find weapons that can shoot in bursts and empty clips faster more useful with loader. (Assault Rifle, Heavy Machine Gun) Overall, most weapons with larger bursts don't have much recovery time or can dish out tons of damage once it actually get's started firing and recovery time won't matter as much, but takes forever to reload.
-
Compensator works better for weapons that have larger clips also, but that don't shoot in bursts (CK-Magellan, Semi-Auto Shotgun). Most of these sorts of weapons also benefit from reload, but these kinds of weapons have abilities where reloading isn't as dangerous (Long Range and Area-of-Effect Knockdown, respectively both with high accuracy) (making this an appropriate comparison, cause I know weapons like Sparrowhawk and Pump Action Shotgun, which are single shots hugely benefit from compensator but really can't compare cause they act differently between shooting/reload/recover).
-
Overall you want to compensate for each weapon's weakness.
Assault Rifle style guns have decent recovery and fire rate so reloading and getting your gun ready would benefit it much more. Of course there is some exception to this idea. If you have multiple weapons Compensator will effect multiple weapons while Loader only effects your first reload. But if you're only worried about using a setup like Assault Rifle then something like another Assault Rifle type weapon or other weapon with a large clip would be fine. I say that because Loader will only work if you reload, and most of the time troopers switch weapons before reloading and usually they start with reloading whatever weapon they have out at the time.
-
Ex.
My unit Munitions unit Barbarian has an Infernal Tube and Sniper and Reload I have tried both weapons as favorite and here's what happens.
If I set Sniper first he will Shoot Sniper and then Loader the Sniper and then shoots and switches to Infernal Tube.
If I set Infernal Tube First it varies. Assume at this point Barbarian has not shot a single thing and has Munitions activated and has an extra shell for the Infernal Tube. He fires the tube, then either Loaders or switches to Sniper and Loaders that. Either situation suits him fine since he's auxillary in my army, but the idea I'm trying to get across is that Loader is random if you have multiple weapons where as Compensator is fixed, is always active, and you know exactly how they work.

On april 6, 2012
SilentPinoy

Take what you can get. I can personally say I love the shotguns on my spies, and the setups they have are very effective.
-
Spy: Rogue
Prominent Combo: Pump Action Shotgun + Compensator + Frenetic
Comments: Unloads rapid fire dispatches, not as strong as Paladin, but reliable knock downs with speed.
-
Spy: Paladin
Prominent Combo: Scattergun + Hydroshock Shells + Frenetic
Comments: Not as fast as Rogue, but much more reliable in deaths per bullet to stack Frenetic.
-
Spy: Wizard
Prominent Combo: Desert Eagle (Or Unarmed) + On Point + Twinoid + Frenetic
Comments: Not as useful as either Rogue or Paladin, but to prove a point, a weapon that is single target such as a Desert Eagle or Famas isn't that effective on an assaulter type spy. Spies for me are most effective taking time, initiative, life, and even attention from as many opponents as possible and making the rest of your army safe.
-
I do have to acknowledge machine guns are very effective on spies also, I just prefer shotguns because of the knockdown, accuracy, and faster reloads.

SilentPinoy

It's all on preferance. If you miss with a machine gun or get only 1-2 targets he's a sitting duck while reloading (if he doesn't have twinoid/loader/frenetic/etc.) for the other target(s). But as a counter the common view is that if you deploy your spy it's 5 vs 3 and killing 1-2 units early is huge. Most armies will have a tactic against spies at this length of the game (either Aim for Closest + Prioirity Spy + Defensive Fighting Style), and if your spy's target moves while you're holding a machine gun your aim does go down more (the reason why Biped upgrade exists), in addition to the poor aim of the machine gun. If you don't have Battle-Ready or using the fully loaded Heavy Machine Gun, you sometimes also only start with minimal bullets. At least with a shotgun 1 bullet can hit multiple targets and cause knockdown. But we could argue about this for awhile, my preference and current army uses shotguns.

On april 23, 2012
[1841726]

Alphakoka your army's set-up is also a determining factor. Armies with sabotage have this grudge against you? Badly itching to acquire a specific helmet? Maybe a smart is a right choice. mostek and ck-magellan comes into play if you want a strong "support" foundation. Like maybe you have observe that your troopers have a hard time closing in and that they are killed or badly wounded before they can get to firing range, then you need a strong long-range trooper in the form of the two super snipers.
Technically, smart is the better choice because with three choices one has a better chance of acquiring more compatible skills later on. Here's an analogy, a trooper with a starting ck-magellan will have a lower chance of acquiring a smart skill while a trooper with a starting smart skill will have a higher chance of acquiring a ck-magellan. So ideally option c is the best choice. But don't you ignore gut or instictive decision.a great poet once said"Follow that mysterious string that is pulling your heart, It won't lead you astray. "

You are quite able to start a trooper with CK-M along with one of the starter weapons, then pick up smart later - but you have zero chance to follow the proposed option E of waiting for a CK-M and Smart trooper in the market.

Cripto

Commando or rocket launcher?
What he has: Doctor, assault rifle, eye of the tiger, on point, zigzag, bait, tucknroll.What did you take?
*
If I'd read the thread yesterday, I would have suggested rocket launcher with your current skills. Rocket launcher + on point is a great combination. At the moment, you haven't got anything to really make use of on point, and Initiative is one of, if not the most important thing in every fight (imo). An army can completely wipe out another army just by being the first to attack, and a rocket launcher is capable of doing that with on point. Your eye of the tiger can even increase its accuracy to the point where it'll hit its target almost 100% of the time if the enemy doesn't have evasive skills of their own.
*
More lifepoints is great and all, but using your trooper only as a tank is limiting his effectiveness. My 2 cents, for what its worth now

On may 1, 2012
Sjaelen

Munitions works if the trooper is actually on the battlefield.

If he's in a later wave of your army, it won't take effect until he joins. If he dies, it stops.

It's incredibly helpful against rats and large armies.
On may 1, 2012
egin

On may 1, 2012
Sjaelen

When you kill off an enemy wave, he reloads the cartridges of your troopers.

Only if he is alive and on the battlefield.

The description is slightly misleading, but he can keep reloading a certain number of times (depends on his level) if he lives through multiple enemy waves.

Kompera

More generically:

If a Trooper has 2 equipment already, are there some you'd skip in favor of waiting to hope to see others offered?

There are some I simply cannot judge their effectiveness, such as Tripod and Flash Bang (I get hit all the time by Blinded Troopers), etc.

Some abilities are used all the time. but others (ex: grenades) are used at a random time. Hurry makes them be used 2x faster (more chance of being used before death)

hurry only really affect skills that don't happen 100% of the time.

On may 10, 2012
SilentPinoy

My units Fighter and Monk have hurry, it's great so they can rush in and kill things very fast. Fighter has hurry which stacks explosive shells use and lets him use his initial infernal tube that much faster, and Monk has hurry to increase his vast action/move speed and dodge roll more often.

However for you it depends on what you like. A 10% action boost is always good (initiative and speed, not to be confused with move speed) is great, but this unit doesn't have much in using abilities and equipment. If you make him start with the desert eagle (my all time favorite weapon) with hurry getting heartbreakers will be crazy, if I am to believe hurry procs hydroshocks and heartbreaker more often.

Of his 3 weapons, 2 of them are pretty long range. Zigzag will only work if the unit moves, not that it isn't viable since he's a sprinter. If you have him as a defender, at any moment he moves away zigzag will proc improving his survival. But for me I hate defender style since it's unreliable short range.

tl:dr - I stand by hurry as the choice.

On may 30, 2012
Pause

Off Topic
The real problem with armor is the cost of the equipment slot, unlike HP boosting skills and dodge skills which can accumulate with other skills (not replace them).
For raid troopers armor is fine but for long term troops armor is not a good idea.

level 1 skill Bulletproof Vest, one equipment slot used.
"Halves the chance of taking a fatal shot to the torso." 1/2 = 0.5

level 1 skill Heartbreaker, no equipment slot needed.
"Chances of inflicting a fatal shot to the heart multiplied by 3" 1*3 = 3

lets say these two troopers meet on the battlefield...
(1/2)*3 = 1.5
Thats 1.5 chances of a fatal shot to the heart, heartbreaker wins and they don't even need to use an equipment slot.

On june 4, 2012
SilentPinoy

It's time to confer my arrangement's once more. However today is a little tricky. I'm dealing with my optimal arrangement when I have a light tank deployed also and mainly focusing on Wave 1.

I've attempted to make a new arrangement for my new addition of Druid. Here's what I have for optimal options.

Name [Class] (Basic Notes) -Favorite Weapon- {Noted Concern}

Wizard [Spy] (Main Spy Deployment, Light Tank) -Double-Barrel Shotgun-
Rogue [Spy] (Secondary Spy Deployment) -Pump-Action Shotgun-
Fighter [Comms.] (Survivor) -Infernal Tube-
Bard [Ammo] (Bait, Light Tank) -CK-Magellan-
Cleric [Doc.] (Savior) -Pump-Action Shotgun-
Ranger [Comms.] (Survivor, Talky-Walky) -M-16- {Note 1}
Barbarian [Ammo] -Infernal Tube- {Note 2}
Sorcerer [Doc.] -Lizaro Jungle-
Paladin [Spy] (Vs 12 Spy Deployment, Light Tank) -Scattergun- {Note 3}
Druid [Soldier] -CK-Magellan-
Monk [Comms.] -Semi-Auto Shotgun-

Basic Overview:
Compared to my last order that took more advantage of early wave chaos caused by my spies and concentrated on minimum aggression from the main army, this order I'm looking into an even more aggressive and supportive structure to my spy deployment in exchange for a lesser defence. I say this because originally I had my Spy "Paladin" deploy in my first wave if I was facing an army with less than 12 units to have an initiative and short range counter against spies along with Cleric. However I'm attempting this order for a wave 1 massacre strategy.

Wave basics:
-Wizard and Rogue spy deploy.
Basically these are my most efficient spies in terms of taking out multiple units. Paladin is technically the strongest, but I need chaos in terms of speed here.

-Wave 1 Consists of Fighter, Bard, Cleric, and Ranger
Fighter Provides anti-vehicle options(Infernal Tube, Explosive Shells), Bard provides spy protection, covering fire sniper counters, and ammo, Cleric revives a unit(preferably Bard) and heals, Ranger has Talky-Walky and decent kill options. Both comms. officers have survivor so they will recover their Comms. Points upon revival.

-With Tank(Wizard/Paladin) Fighter and Bard will provide long range support and Paladin will be spy deployed if Wizard tank deploys.
-With Tank(Bard) Cleric replaces Bard for support.
With 3 chances for a tank to deploy this has become an important factor in my order. I use my tanks as a great meat shield, 2 of my tanks are spy units which many armies select main target as spy and Bard has Bait to take the brunt of hits. Fighter and Bard have long range weapons and can stay behind the tank unit to provide support and Bard provides ammo.
{Note 1} My original use of the Talky-Walky was to call in my Rambo unit "Monk" to take advantage of the initiative bonus as well as his high speed to make a grand entrance. This was generally optimal because he is a comms. unit without revive so placing him last would allow comms. commands throughout the battle. If I wish to maintain this dynamic it relinquishes Ranger's survivor to hope for Cleric's Savior to work or placing Druid as my last unit. Option 1 requires too many factors for it to work and option 2 is bad as Druid does not have the comeback factor in case I am behind in the battle that Monk has.

-With Enemy Spy in wave 1, Ranger is not deployed
Important for wave 2 and main reason why he isn't in order before Cleric for Tank support. I need as lesser amounts of deaths as possible in case of a spy wipeout. Best case scenario, Cleric revived a unit and Fighter doesn't count under wave 2 deployment if wave 1 is spy wiped. Fighter revives, Ranger, Barbarian, Sorcerer, and Paladin are summoned, Ranger calls in Druid. Druid and Paladin would have initiative advantages and be able to dispatch threats.

-In a normal deployment, Ranger calls in Barbarian
Talky-Walky provides an initiative bonus to the summoned unit. Calling in another Infernal Tube will provide massive attack damage. This is important in the early waves as enemy vehicles are more likely deployed 1st wave. Also once the Tube has been used, Barbarian switches to a different weapon becoming faster and more useful.
{Note 2} Looking at all my units that can use the Talky-Walky initiative bonus most effectively, it was cut down to Monk, Paladin, and Barbarian. Druid may have the chance if he obtains firing/kill skills while I'm still training him. Monk I need last for many reasons, and Paladin does not have enough time to influence a battle due to short range weapons. Barbarian takes advantage of this the most, however there's a few issues with this. Barbarian is a munitions unit, if Bard survives the first wave it effectively wastes that ability. Another problem is his inability to safely deal with a close range opponent. I'm highly considering putting Druid into the slot later once he gets more levels.

-If Fighter and/or Ranger dies, but I win the first wave.
Survivor is a strange factor in my unit composition, providing second chances for my team. I hope at any point where these units die I hope that they recover while either of my doctors are available. This skill affixes my wave 1 dominance if I maintain my spies and my long ranger support. But at the same time they may simply be fodder because with 1 HP they are simply easy.

-If first wave goes optimally all according to plan, wave 2 deploys with Sorcerer, Paladin, Druid, and Monk.
However, there are times where Ranger and Fighter will take up one or both of the incoming wave deployment points. This isn't really a bad thing. Monk is a fantastic solo unit and having a ranged support would make for a good duo or even trio (via Cleric Savior) comeback possibility.

-Wave 3 main possibility
Druid, Monk, and Savior'd Unit (Fighter/Bard/Ranger)
The interesting dynamic here is the possibilities that come from the combinations.
-Fighter and Ranger provide a guaranteed 20 comms. points for propganda.
-Fighter has an Infernal Tube that has strange equalizer chances.
-Bard is my most reliable attack support unit. With Bait he allows Monk to freely go crazy and kill everything. Covering Fire allows him to be safe.
-I put Druid in the back because if a Savior'd unit is not there, Druid has at least long range capabilities and can take hits.

I want to improve upon this order, there may be a chance when I get Druid to 11. Here's to hoping he obtains good skills, maybe since he's a soldier and has unshakable and a protection vest I can make him a dedicated tank unit. If he get's the skills I'll make this an amazing army tool with him.
